articles.headline: Sam Bankman-Fried Should Get 40 to 50 Years in Prison, Prosecutors Say
articles.snippet: Mr. Bankman-Fried, who was convicted of seven counts of fraud and conspiracy, faces a maximum penalty of 110 years.
articles.abstract: Mr. Bankman-Fried, who was convicted of seven counts of fraud and conspiracy, faces a maximum penalty of 110 years.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors said on Friday that Sam Bankman-Fried, the cryptocurrency mogul who was convicted of masterminding a multibillion-dollar fraud, should receive a prison sentence of 40 to 50 years.
articles.byline: By Matthew Goldstein and David Yaffe-Bellany

articles.headline: Kushner Developing Deals Overseas Even as His Father-in-Law Runs for President
articles.snippet: Donald Trump’s son-in-law, who was also a senior White House official, said he was close to finalizing real estate projects in Albania and Serbia.
articles.abstract: Donald Trump’s son-in-law, who was also a senior White House official, said he was close to finalizing real estate projects in Albania and Serbia.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jared Kushner, the son-in-law of Donald J. Trump, confirmed on Friday that he was closing in on major real estate deals in Albania and Serbia, the latest example of the former president’s family doing business abroad even as Mr. Trump seeks to return to the White House.
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton, Jonathan Swan and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Judge Rules D.A. Can Stay on Trump Georgia Case With Ex-Boyfriend Stepping Down
articles.snippet: The highly anticipated ruling cut a middle path between removing Fani T. Willis for a conflict of interest and her full vindication.
articles.abstract: The highly anticipated ruling cut a middle path between removing Fani T. Willis for a conflict of interest and her full vindication.
articles.lead_paragraph: An Atlanta judge ruled on Friday that Fani T. Willis, the Fulton County district attorney, could continue leading the election interference prosecution of former President Donald J. Trump and his allies in Georgia, but only if her former romantic partner, Nathan J. Wade, withdrew from the case.
articles.byline: By Richard Fausset and Danny Hakim

articles.headline: Another Gaza Aid Convoy Ends in Violence, With at Least 20 Killed
articles.snippet: The Gaza Health Ministry accused Israel of a “targeted” attack. Israel’s military denied the accusation, blaming Palestinian gunmen for the violence.
articles.abstract: The Gaza Health Ministry accused Israel of a “targeted” attack. Israel’s military denied the accusation, blaming Palestinian gunmen for the violence.
articles.lead_paragraph: For at least the second time in just over two weeks, a convoy bringing aid to hunger-stricken northern Gaza ended in bloodshed late Thursday when Palestinians were killed and wounded in an attack surrounding the trucks, according to Gazan health officials and the Israeli military, which offered divergent accounts of what happened.
articles.byline: By Raja Abdulrahim and Anushka Patil

articles.headline: Sheriff Had Cause to Take Maine Gunman Into Custody Before Shootings
articles.snippet: An interim report from a commission investigating the mass shooting in Lewiston, Maine, found that the gunman’s weapons could and should have been removed.
articles.abstract: An interim report from a commission investigating the mass shooting in Lewiston, Maine, found that the gunman’s weapons could and should have been removed.
articles.lead_paragraph: A commission investigating the mass shooting in Lewiston, Maine, concluded on Friday that local law enforcement officers should have taken the gunman into custody and seized his weapons before he killed 18 people on Oct. 25.
articles.byline: By Jenna Russell

articles.headline: TikTok Bill’s Progress Slows in the Senate
articles.snippet: Legislation to force TikTok’s Chinese owner to sell the app or have it banned in the United States sailed through the House, but the Senate has no plans to move hastily.
articles.abstract: Legislation to force TikTok’s Chinese owner to sell the app or have it banned in the United States sailed through the House, but the Senate has no plans to move hastily.
articles.lead_paragraph: After a bill that would force TikTok’s Chinese parent company to sell the app or face a nationwide ban sailed through the House at breakneck speed this week, its progress has slowed in the Senate.
articles.byline: By David McCabe and Sapna Maheshwari

articles.headline: Mike Lynch, Former U.K. Tech Mogul, Faces the Trial of His Life
articles.snippet: A criminal trial is set to begin for Mr. Lynch, the founder of the software company Autonomy, which was sold to Hewlett-Packard in 2011 and later accused of being a fraud.
articles.abstract: A criminal trial is set to begin for Mr. Lynch, the founder of the software company Autonomy, which was sold to Hewlett-Packard in 2011 and later accused of being a fraud.
articles.lead_paragraph: Every morning in his townhouse in the tony San Francisco neighborhood of Pacific Heights, the man once referred to as Britain’s Bill Gates gets to work.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Driving With Mr. Gil: A Retiree Teaches Afghan Women the Rules of the Road
articles.snippet: Local lore says that one 82-year-old professor has probably taught more Afghan women drivers in a California town than there are in all Afghanistan. For them, it’s not about empowerment; it’s for groceries.
articles.abstract: Local lore says that one 82-year-old professor has probably taught more Afghan women drivers in a California town than there are in all Afghanistan. For them, it’s not about empowerment; it’s for groceries.
articles.lead_paragraph: Bibifatima Akhundzada wove a white Chevy Spark through downtown Modesto, Calif., on a recent morning, practicing turns, braking and navigating intersections.
articles.byline: By Miriam Jordan and Rachel Bujalski

articles.headline: How Trump Is Scrambling to Raise Cash
articles.snippet: The former president is facing converging financial crunches as he and the Republican Party confront a shortfall against President Biden and the Democrats.
articles.abstract: The former president is facing converging financial crunches as he and the Republican Party confront a shortfall against President Biden and the Democrats.
articles.lead_paragraph: As many as three nights a week, Donald J. Trump has been hosting private dinners at Mar-a-Lago, schmoozing with some of the Republican Party’s biggest financiers as he races to address a sizable cash shortfall against President Biden.
articles.byline: By Shane Goldmacher and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Landline Users Remain Proudly ‘Old-Fashioned’ in the Digital Age
articles.snippet: Traditional phones may seem like relics in the iPhone era, but a recent AT&T cellular service outage had some landline lovers extolling their virtues.
articles.abstract: Traditional phones may seem like relics in the iPhone era, but a recent AT&T cellular service outage had some landline lovers extolling their virtues.
articles.lead_paragraph: When millions of AT&T customers across the country briefly lost their cellphone service last month, Francella Jackson, 61, of Fairview Heights, Ill., said she picked up her well-worn Southwestern Bell push-button landline phone and called her friends “just so we could laugh at the people who could not use their phones.”
articles.byline: By Michael Levenson

articles.headline: How Trump’s Allies Are Winning the War Over Disinformation
articles.snippet: Their claims of censorship have successfully stymied the effort to filter election lies online.
articles.abstract: Their claims of censorship have successfully stymied the effort to filter election lies online.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the wake of the riot on Capitol Hill on Jan. 6, 2021, a groundswell built in Washington to rein in the onslaught of lies that had fueled the assault on the peaceful transfer of power.
articles.byline: By Jim Rutenberg and Steven Lee Myers

articles.headline: Piety and Profanity: The Raunchy Christians Are Here
articles.snippet: In the Trump era, a surprising number of evangelicals are rejecting modesty and turning toward the risqué.
articles.abstract: In the Trump era, a surprising number of evangelicals are rejecting modesty and turning toward the risqué.
articles.lead_paragraph: The “Conservative Dad’s Real Women of America” 2024 pinup calendar features old-school images of sexiness — bikinis, a red sports car, a bubble bath.
articles.byline: By Ruth Graham

articles.headline: Long Lines of Russian Voters Signal Discontent With Putin’s Tenure
articles.snippet: Many appeared to be heeding a call by the opposition to express frustration by showing up en masse at midday. “We don’t have any other options,” said one woman.
articles.abstract: Many appeared to be heeding a call by the opposition to express frustration by showing up en masse at midday. “We don’t have any other options,” said one woman.
articles.lead_paragraph: Russian voters formed long lines outside polling stations in major cities during the presidential election on Sunday, with many saying they were heeding a call by opposition leaders to protest a rubber-stamp process that is certain to keep Vladimir V. Putin in power.
articles.byline: By Anatoly Kurmanaev and Nanna Heitmann

articles.headline: In Latest A.I. War Escalation, Elon Musk Releases Chatbot Code
articles.snippet: Mr. Musk’s move to open up the code behind Grok is the latest volley in a war to win the A.I. battle, after a suit against OpenAI on the same topic.
articles.abstract: Mr. Musk’s move to open up the code behind Grok is the latest volley in a war to win the A.I. battle, after a suit against OpenAI on the same topic.
articles.lead_paragraph: Elon Musk released the raw computer code behind his version of an artificial intelligence chatbot on Sunday, an escalation by one of the world’s richest men in a battle to control the future of A.I.
articles.byline: By Kate Conger and Cade Metz

articles.headline: Student Housing Pioneer Faces Angry Investors, Irate Judges and a $115 Million Bill
articles.snippet: Patrick Nelson, who manages 18 student housing properties, is struggling to pay back his partners. He says the pandemic harmed his once-thriving business.
articles.abstract: Patrick Nelson, who manages 18 student housing properties, is struggling to pay back his partners. He says the pandemic harmed his once-thriving business.
articles.lead_paragraph: Patrick S. Nelson is a man under siege.
articles.byline: By Matthew Goldstein

articles.headline: Supreme Court Wary of States’ Bid to Limit Federal Contact With Social Media Companies
articles.snippet: The justices tried to distinguish between persuading social media sites to take down posts, which is permitted, and coercing them, which violates the First Amendment.
articles.abstract: The justices tried to distinguish between persuading social media sites to take down posts, which is permitted, and coercing them, which violates the First Amendment.
articles.lead_paragraph: A majority of the Supreme Court seemed wary on Monday of a bid by two Republican-led states to limit the Biden administration’s interactions with social media companies, with several justices questioning the states’ legal theories and factual assertions.
articles.byline: By Adam Liptak

articles.headline: Gambia Moves Toward Overturning Landmark Ban on Female Genital Cutting
articles.snippet: Lawmakers in the West African country voted to advance a bill repealing a 2015 ban. If it passes the final round of voting, Gambia will become the first nation to roll back protections against the practice.
articles.abstract: Lawmakers in the West African country voted to advance a bill repealing a 2015 ban. If it passes the final round of voting, Gambia will become the first nation to roll back protections against the practice.
articles.lead_paragraph: Gambian lawmakers have voted to advance a measure revoking a ban on female genital cutting by removing legal protections for millions of girls, raising fears that other countries could follow suit.
articles.byline: By Ruth Maclean

articles.headline: Behind Putin’s Potemkin Vote, Real Support. But No Other Choices.
articles.snippet: Many Russians say they back their president, but it is far less clear what they might do if they were given alternatives.
articles.abstract: Many Russians say they back their president, but it is far less clear what they might do if they were given alternatives.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Kremlin stage-managed Russia’s presidential vote over the weekend to send a singular message at home and abroad: that President Vladimir V. Putin’s support is overwhelming and unshakable, despite or even because of his war against Ukraine.
articles.byline: By Paul Sonne

articles.headline: VW Workers Seek Union Vote at Tennessee Plant for Third Time
articles.snippet: The United Automobile Workers said a “supermajority” of the 4,000 eligible workers at a Volkswagen factory had signed cards backing the union.
articles.abstract: The United Automobile Workers said a “supermajority” of the 4,000 eligible workers at a Volkswagen factory had signed cards backing the union.
articles.lead_paragraph: Volkswagen employees in Tennessee who are hoping to join the United Automobile Workers asked a federal agency on Monday to hold an election, a key step toward the union’s longtime goal of organizing nonunion factories across the South.
articles.byline: By Neal E. Boudette

articles.headline: Tesla’s Troubles Raise Questions About Its Invincibility
articles.snippet: As the share price plunges, investors wonder whether the company, led by Elon Musk, can withstand intensifying competition.
articles.abstract: As the share price plunges, investors wonder whether the company, led by Elon Musk, can withstand intensifying competition.
articles.lead_paragraph: Elon Musk appeared to be in a defiant mood Wednesday when he stood before employees at Tesla’s factory near Berlin a week after an arsonist set fire to a high-voltage power pylon and brought production to a standstill.
articles.byline: By Melissa Eddy and Jack Ewing
